item.title: Sharon K. Goetz on "Alternatives to InDesign for creating multimedia ebooks?"
item.dc:creator: Sharon K. Goetz
item.description: An update to my own earlier comment and a partial reply to Wally Grotophorst's: I have since had cause to use Sigil to correct the imperfect epub export produced by current Calibre. I would very much recommend Sigil over Calibre for epub2 at this point. (The document in question was a "reprint" collection of stories, poems, and review essays for a webzine, and thus with some visual complications--indented lines of verse--as well as structural requirements analogous to a chaptered book's.)

item.title: Kevin Hawkins on "Alternatives to InDesign for creating multimedia ebooks?"
item.dc:creator: Kevin Hawkins
item.description:
Amazon sells books in print and in formats that can be read by Amazon Kindle devices. Sound and film obviously cannot be in a print book, and I believe that the Kindle formats do not yet support these either. (On the other hand, iBooks Author allows you to create ebooks with these types of media, but then they can be used on Apple, not Amazon, devices.)

So you will need to determine whether you are willing to omit some of your content in the version sold on Amazon in order to reach the audience found there.

item.title: Kevin Hawkins on "Alternatives to InDesign for creating multimedia ebooks?"
item.dc:creator: Kevin Hawkins
item.description:
On Miriam's original question on this thread, if you aren't in a position to start with webpages or TEI and want to be able to work with things more visually, see Wikipedia's list of free desktop publishing software. Some of these may be able to produce EPUB files as InDesign can, and they may let you embed multimedia content.

The easy-to-use tool for creating multimedia ebooks is iBooks Author, but your content is then locked into Apple's proprietary flavor of EPUB or in PDF and can only be read on an iPad. See our guide to iBooks Author.

As for Pedram's recent question on this thread, there is no simple answer here. Answers to a few questions will help guide you in the right direction:

a) Do you need for this book to be sold as an e-book on Amazon, in the iBook Store, or in another retail outlet? Or are you content to put files on your own website and let people download from there?

b) Do you need for a user to be able to read the book on an e-reader, or is it okay to require them to have a web browser?

item.title: Arno Bosse on "Alternatives to InDesign for creating multimedia ebooks?"
item.dc:creator: Arno Bosse
item.description:
I just discovered that Apple's Pages can export documents into .epub (in that sense it's a similar suggestion to Scrivener, which I'll have to try out next). I've tested the Pages epub export feature with text documents that included images, tables and footnotes - all were converted into epub without issues (i.e. I confirmed that it looked and worked as expected on an iPhone, with the Adobe Digital Editions app and that the files could be opened with Calbre and Sigil).

[Update] I see that there is an excellent discussion of the pros and cons of exporting epub from Pages and Scrivener on the ThreePress Blog.

On a related note, if you're specifically targeting the iphone/ipad I know that there was a session at WWDC 2011 that described best practices for how to create both flowing text and fixed layout (epub based) ebooks (including features like embedded HTML5 video and audio) for these devices. Unfortunately the content of the video & the slides for the session are still under non-disclosure. Check back in a few weeks if you're not a registered Apple developer.

item.title: ajgulyas@gmail.com on "iAnnotate vs. GoodReader?"
item.dc:creator: ajgulyas@gmail.com
item.description:
I've been using GoodReader for a few months and it seems to work well for this sort of thing. I can bring in PDFs from Dropbox, FTP, box.net, Google Docs, etc. It also has a built-in web browser so I can get to JSTOR, or other repository, and download PDFs of articles fairly directly.

As for annotations, I use the highlighting most in GoodReader-- not sure how well it exports to other viewers though.

item.title: Mark Sample on "iAnnotate vs. GoodReader?"
item.dc:creator: Mark Sample
item.description: I haven't used GoodReader, but I do use iAnnotate (based on some recommendations from my Twitter feed), and I find it quite good. It's a breeze to pull in PDFs from Dropbox or from websites. The highlighting and annotations work well, and best of all, they're readable with other PDF viewers.

item.title: Moacir P. de Sá Pereira on "iAnnotate vs. GoodReader?"
item.dc:creator: Moacir P. de Sá Pereira
item.description:
It's Christmas at my household, which means that I can finally ask this question. I have been using GoodReader on my phone, and I generally like the wide array of means by which one can get to files, the reading experience in general, and the annotation seems a bit clunky, but good enough.

My friend refuses to believe that there is a program for reading scholarly journals, chapters of books, things one has scanned, etc. that is better than iAnnotate.

How do you all feel? Has anyone tried both? I can't really say money is the issue (since I decided that I apparently *need* FIFA11 on my iPad right after springing for GoodReader), but I would like to avoid getting heavily into the groove on one program or the other on the device and then switching up after succumbing to pressure from my DH peers.

item.title: Wally Grotophorst on "Alternatives to InDesign for creating multimedia ebooks?"
item.dc:creator: Wally Grotophorst
item.description:
One more suggestion (Mac only)

Over the past week or so I've been using Scrivener 2.0 for Mac. It has the ability to export .epub as well as .mobi (for Kindle) files. I haven't tried epub as I'm a Kindle user but I can tell you Scrivener does a very nice job producing multimedia (e.g., text and images) documents for Kindle. You have to go to Amazon and download their free kindlegen utility (Scrivener walks you through that one-time process) and then it's really as simple as click and publish to any number of formats.

RTF, PDF, Word (doc,docx), Open Office (.odt), ePub, Kindle (.mobi), html, plain text and few others (e.g., multimarkdown)

item.title: Dorothea Salo on "Alternatives to InDesign for creating multimedia ebooks?"
item.dc:creator: Dorothea Salo
item.description: Slight caution with Sophie: its developers (mighty and brilliant though they are) have a history of abandoning projects. Also, you will be cutting off a lot of your potential audience if you require a software download, no matter how cross-platform (and no iOS or Android support would give me pause as well).

item.title: Mark Sample on "Alternatives to InDesign for creating multimedia ebooks?"
item.dc:creator: Mark Sample
item.description:
I'm surprised nobody has mentioned Sophie, an open source project from the Institute for the Future of the Book. Sophie is especially designed as a platform to create media-rich, interactive books.

The chief drawback of Sophie is that Sophie ebooks require the Sophie Reader. But that's not so much of a drawback when you consider that the Sophie Reader runs on Windows, Mac, and Linux.

item.title: Miriam Posner on "Alternatives to InDesign for creating multimedia ebooks?"
item.dc:creator: Miriam Posner
item.description:
Replying to @Patrick Murray-John's post:

Patrick, I love Anthologize and would personally love to see multimedia support. I'll file a ticket! I don't know how common multimedia ebooks are -- as you can tell, I'm still figuring this whole ebook thing out -- but what I'm hearing from grad students is something along the lines of, "I have this awesome [public domain] work that I know better than anyone else in the world, and I'd really like to create an ebook that's enriched with multimedia annotation." I'm wondering how I can help support this.

I really like the idea of going from WordPress, which a number of grad students are already familiar with, to a multimedia-enhanced Anthologize ebook.

And thanks again, all. This has really helped me figure out which questions I need to be asking about which technologies. Googling was leading me down too many garden paths.
